Suggest to Peter that a better (smoother) fitness function could be
the sum=
 of altitudes over a series of discrete time steps.  I have
been experiment=
ing with a similar biped.  I have only implemented some
variations on Hebbi=
an rules thus far, with little success.  However I
have seen evidence that =
taking the altitude across several points on
the multibody (head, torso, pe=
lvis) seems to lend itself to refining
the fitness function.  I have yet to=
 try it but I am willing to bet
that if you use a fitness function that pun=
ishes being above a certain
target altitude (or sum of altitudes) it is pos=
sible to evolve
standing behaviors without the exploit of flipping, leaping=
, and
generally abusing a powerful body.
ck

I have been stalling on making the

ally using the new python

> >> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Miguel" <cesa=
r.gomes@> wrote:
> >> >
> >> > Peter B. and I have been doing some experime=
nts with Breve
using the
> >> > NEAT-Python implementation. It's not a plug=
in, though. You have
to set
> >> > up a fitness function that calls the Bre=
ve engine from the command
> >> > line and passes the chromosomes by argume=
nt. Once the Breve
simulation
> >> > is finished, it returns the fitness fo=
r each individual.
> >> >
> >> > So it's a two-step problem: first set-up y=
our environment within
> >> > Breve, as you'd do in a normal experiment; th=
en you define a
fitness
> >> > function to load that environment every time=
 you need to
evaluate the
> >> > population. Think of Breve as the "evaluat=
or" and not part of NEAT.
> >> > It's a completely separated module.
> >> >=

> >> > If you have interest, we can send you the code. It only works
in li=
nux
> >> > right now, given that you need to use some shell scripts. But I
=
think
> >> > it won't be hard to translate that into a bat file.
> >> >
> >=
> > Cesar
> >> >

ll

hyperNEAT plugin for the breve

rite one, if someone points me

ht c/c++ version.
